A.caption: In 1957, the Geodesic Dome was originally built on campus. As the need for experimental projects grew, the search began for a better space to expand.
In 1959, a thesis identified Brizzolara Creek as the prime location. The study included a detailed map of the area, photos of the existing road, and conceptual sketches of potential structures.
In 1961, George Hasslein, advocating for the new space, stands on the newly built suspension bridge spanning Brizzolara Creek.

B.caption: In 1963, the Blade Structure became the first official project in what would later be known as Poly Canyon. The blade pointed to the original boundary corners of the site.
Shortly after, the Geodesic Dome was moved and reconstructed in the canyon by a group of students, cementing the space as a hub for innovation.
Over the next few years, projects flourished. The Shell House emerged as a standout, featuring a unique shell-inspired design at the time.
The Bridge House and other major structures that stand today began to take shape during this period, showcasing the canyon’s ambition.
By the late 1960s, infrastructure expanded significantly. A water tank was installed, and electrical transformers, like the one shown here, were set up to power the canyon.

C.caption: In 1973, the canyon saw increased activity and visitors. Its first caretaker played a crucial role, helping construct the Techite Bridge to support the area’s growing needs.
In 1974, with George Hasslein’s support, the first Design Village competition took place. Students are seen here arriving by bus to participate in this groundbreaking event.
Later that year, work continued on the Hydraulic House, a striking example of how innovation and experimentation thrived in the canyon.
Design Village became a defining feature of the canyon’s identity. In 1984, National Geographic captured the spirit of the event with a featured photo of the competition.
By the end of this era, momentum surged with innovative projects like the Greenhouse while structures like the Stick House provided valuable educational experiences.

D.caption: The Modular House showcased how the canyon continued to push structural evolution, with caretakers playing a central role in its development.
Early in this era, structures like the Cantilever Deck were constructed, while older structures were maintained and restored, reflecting a commitment to preservation and growth.
The canyon attracted many visitors, from the annual Design Village crowd of college students to younger audiences like touring elementary school classes.

E.caption: Shortly after caretakers moved out in 2011, graffiti began to spread across nearly every structure.
In response to the destruction, maintenance groups formed. The Canyon Days team, shown here, worked together to repair, convert structures, and paint over graffiti.
Design Village carried on strong, passing the flame year after year to keep the spirit of student building alive.
Over time, these maintenance groups faded, and most structures were stripped down and converted into open-air remnants.
The canyon’s new identity as the "Architecture Graveyard" took hold, spreading online. Bloggers and influencers visited to share their experiences of this now hauntingly iconic space.
Yet, life goes on. Here, horses grazing in front of a recently built structure highlight a simple truth: the canyon itself remains alive, evolving, and filled with potential.

F.caption: The canyon still bursts with activity and spirit. Here, members of a hammock club enjoy the Poly Pavilion in a stunning photo.
Projects continue to rise, driven by students with a passion for improvement. The Moment Monument, built in 2024, serves as an educational piece.
Design Village remains a groundbreaking event where first-year Cal Poly students and teams from other schools come together for a unique architectural competition.
And of course, the canyon still faces challenges, awaiting the next generation of students ready to tackle them and shape its future.
